questions.text: Which item below does not qualify as personal protective equipment? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lab coat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are:
  • ➤ Gloves - protect hands. Gowns/ aprons - protect skin and clothing. Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents. Goggles - protect eyes. Face shields - protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes.
  • ➤ Gloves - protect hands.
  • ➤ Gowns/ aprons - protect skin and clothing.
  • ➤ Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents.
  • ➤ Goggles - protect eyes.
  • ➤ Face shields - protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes.

questions.text: What is the recommended time gap between the application of two live vaccines? (NEET PG 2018)

  • ➤ 2 live vaccines can be given together

questions.text: As the in-charge epidemiologist of an urban CHC, you've been reviewing the weekly infectious disease reports. In a particular community under your jurisdiction, you observe that dengue case counts typically range from 40 to 50 cases every week. During your current weekly review, you note there are 48 reported cases of dengue. Based on this data and your understanding of epidemiological terminology, how would you classify this week's situation with respect to dengue? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endemic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endemic: Is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • ➤ Endemic: Is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population

questions.explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following is not constrained by time? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Goal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A goal is the ultimate desired state that a health program aims to achieve. It is not constrained by time, meaning that a goal does not have a specific timeline associated with it. Additionally, a goal is not necessarily attainable , as it represents the ultimate desired outcome.
  • • the ultimate desired state
  • • not have a specific timeline
  • • not necessarily attainable
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Objective: An objective is a specific, planned activity in a health program. Objectives are designed to help achieve the goal and are usually associated with a timeline .
  • • Option A. Objective:
  • • specific, planned activity
  • • timeline
  • • Option B. Target: A target is the degree of achievement of objectives and is always associated with a timeline.
  • • Option B. Target:
  • • degree of achievement
  • • timeline.
  • • Option D. Principle: The principles are generally guidelines or fundamental truths and do not specify timelines.
  • • Option D. Principle:
  • • guidelines or fundamental truths

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of health programs, a goal is the ultimate desired state and is not constrained by time or resources. It represents an " all or none" phenomenon and may not always be attainable.
  • ➤ all or none" phenomenon

questions.text: A female 29 years old is on a Combined OCP regimen for contraception. All of the following cancers may be seen in her except (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ovarian cancer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) have been shown to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. OCPs are protective against benign breast diseases, benign & malignant ovarian diseases but have been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and cervical cancer . Thus, ovarian cancer is the correct answer, as it is the exception.
  • • protective against benign breast diseases, benign & malignant ovarian diseases
  • • increased risk of breast cancer and cervical cancer
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Breast cancer: Combined OCPs may slightly increase the risk of breast cancer.
  • • Option A. Breast cancer:
  • • Option B. Cervical cancer: There is evidence that long-term use of combined OCPs can increase the risk of cervical cancer.
  • • Option B. Cervical cancer:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills reduce the risk of ovarian cancer while potentially increasing the risk of breast and cervical cancers.

questions.text: A patient arrives with a clean-cut injury, no lacerations. He reports receiving his last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago. What would be the recommended course of action? (NEET PG 2020)

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester has a 2-year-old child. She received a complete vaccination course during her last pregnancy. What tetanus immunization is recommended for her now? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Td booster dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For pregnant women who received the complete Td vaccination course during their last pregnancy within the last three years, a Td booster dose is recommended.

questions.text: The following diagram depicts the fluctuation in population over the years spanning from 1983 to 1989 within a specific location. Which type of statistical diagram is being employed in this instance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Component bar graph

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A component bar graph is used to represent data where the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components, effectively illustrating the proportion of each category within the total value.

questions.text: In a screening examination conducted on a population of 1000 individuals for diabetes mellitus (DM), 90 individuals tested positive. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was performed, identifying 100 positive cases. What is the calculated sensitivity? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 90/100

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sensitivity is the proportion of true positive cases correctly identified by a screening test out of all actual positive cases identified by the gold standard test.

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible

options.label: B
options.text: Clear eyes with a sterile swab

options.label: C
options.text: Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.correct_answer: C. Bath to newborn with warm water
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bath to newborn with warm water

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

questions.text: Which of these options is NOT a means of directly transmitting communicable diseases? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Droplet nuclei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Droplet nuclei represent an indirect transmission method, as they can remain airborne for long periods and travel over distances, whereas vertical transmission , contact with soil , and droplet transmission are forms of direct transmission of communicable diseases.
  • ➤ Droplet nuclei
  • ➤ indirect transmission
  • ➤ vertical transmission
  • ➤ contact with soil
  • ➤ droplet transmission
  • ➤ direct transmission

questions.text: In a small coastal town in Kerala, a sudden surge of gastroenteritis cases is reported within two days after a community seafood feast. Health officials suspect the seafood feast as the source of the epidemic. Which of the following statements is true regarding this type of single exposure point source epidemic? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Explosive in nature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Single exposure point source epidemics are explosive in nature with a rapid increase and decline in cases, confined to one incubation period.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to your hospital emergency with pregnancy 22 weeks, which was a result of rape. Correct statement regarding Medical Termination of Pregnancy is? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG

options.label: B
options.text: MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case

options.label: C
options.text: MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother

options.label: D
options.text: MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only

questions.correct_answer: B. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MTP between 20-24 weeks of pregnancy is considered high risk and requires two doctors' opinions, especially in cases of rape, incest, disability, or if the woman is a minor.

questions.text: What is the reservoir of leishmaniasis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Man

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The reservoir of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kalazar or Indian kala-azar, is humans.
  • • Visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar) is caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani. The vector responsible for transmitting the disease is the sandfly (Phlebotomus species).
  • • Visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar) is caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani.
  • • The vector responsible for transmitting the disease is the sandfly (Phlebotomus species).
  • • The reservoir host of the disease is humans (man).
  • • The reservoir host of the disease is humans (man).
  • • Other 3 options are incorrect
  • • Other 3 options are incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar or Indian kala-azar), the reservoir host is humans.

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coefficient of variation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is? (NEET PG 2019)

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy at 22 weeks of gestation for contraceptive failure after 21 weeks requires approval from: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 doctors

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Now, MTP is permitted till 24 weeks of gestation. It is divided into two categories: low-risk MTP and high-risk MTP.
  • • Low-risk MTP : performed up to 20 weeks of gestation, requires the approval of only one doctor.
  • • Low-risk MTP
  • • High-risk MTP : includes cases where the gestational age is between 20 weeks to 24 weeks, the approval of two doctors is required.
  • • High-risk MTP
  • • The specifies that the MTP is being considered at 22 weeks of gestation, which falls under the high-risk category. Therefore, the approval of two doctors is necessary.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 1 doctor: This option is incorrect because gestational ages above 20 weeks and up to 24 weeks, the approval of two doctors is required.
  • • Option
  • • A. 1 doctor:
  • • Option C. Court: This option is incorrect because court approval is not required for MTP up to 24 weeks of gestation.
  • • Option
  • • C. Court:
  • • Option D. Medical board: This option is incorrect because a medical board's approval is only required for cases involving severe fetal malformations after 24 weeks of gestation, not for the scenario described in the question.
  • • Option
  • • D. Medical board:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For medical termination of pregnancy between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation, which is considered a high-risk category, the approval of two doctors is required.

questions.text: What is Demographic gap? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Crude birth rate – Crude death rate

options.label: B
options.text: Crude birth rate + Crude death rate

options.label: C
options.text: Crude birth rate / Crude death rate

options.label: D
options.text: Crude birth rate × Crude death rate

questions.correct_answer: A. Crude birth rate – Crude death rate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Crude birth rate – Crude death rate

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The demographic gap is defined as the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate, representing the population growth rate

questions.text: What is demographic transition as a country passes through the demographic cycle? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Transition from low literacy levels to high literacy levels

options.label: C
options.text: Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate

Ans. C) Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Demographic transition is characterized by the shift from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as a country progresses through the stages of the demographic cycle.

Sanchol and mORCVAX: Bivalent, Serogroups O1 & O139, No toxin B subunit, No buffer required. 2 liquid doses after the age of 1 year and booster after 2 years. Euvichol: it is just like Sanchol. Bivalent with 2 doses.

questions.text: Under which health program, the School Health was combined in the year 2018? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ayushman Bharat program

  • • Explanation:
  • • In 2018, the School Health program was integrated under the Ayushman Bharat program. This integration involved the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and the Ministry of Human Resource Development. Here, School teachers to be made the Health & Wellness ambassadors
  • • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and the Ministry of Human Resource Development.
  • • Health & Wellness ambassadors
  • • The program focuses on various health initiatives for school children are –
  • • The program focuses on various health initiatives for school children are –
  • • Iron and folic acid supplementation, Deworming with albendazole tablets , Distribution of sanitary napkins to adolescent girls, Age-appropriate vaccination, Maintenance of electronic health records , and Teaching first aid . Additionally, the program is part of the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karikram (RBSK ), targeting the screening of 30 disorders in children.
  • • Iron and folic acid supplementation,
  • • Iron and folic acid supplementation,
  • • Deworming with albendazole tablets ,
  • • Deworming with albendazole tablets
  • • Distribution of sanitary napkins to adolescent girls,
  • • sanitary napkins
  • • Age-appropriate vaccination,
  • • Age-appropriate vaccination,
  • • Maintenance of electronic health records , and
  • • electronic health records
  • • Teaching first aid .
  • • Teaching first aid
  • • Additionally, the program is part of the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karikram (RBSK ), targeting the screening of 30 disorders in children.
  • • Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karikram (RBSK
  • • 30 disorders
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anemia Mukt Bharat program : This program aims to reduce anemia across the population, particularly among women and children, but it is not the program under which the School Health program was integrated in 2018.
  • • Option A. Anemia Mukt Bharat program
  • • Option C. Swachh Bharat Mission : This initiative focuses on cleanliness and sanitation across India but is not related to the School Health program integration.
  • • Option C. Swachh Bharat Mission
  • • Option D. Poshan Abhiyan : This mission targets improving nutritional outcomes for children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers but does not encompass the School Health program's integration.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In 2018, the School Health program was integrated into the Ayushman Bharat program, involving health and wellness initiatives for school children.

questions.text: During disaster management, triage is conducted to ensure proper treatment of casualties. What are the accurate aspects of the triage process carried out at the site of the disaster? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority

options.label: C
options.text: Moribund patients receive the lowest priority

options.label: D
options.text: Most commonly used system is three color code system

questions.correct_answer: C. Moribund patients receive the lowest priority

questions.text: A researcher is studying the spread of a new viral illness. He wants to determine the probability that a susceptible person will contract the disease after close contact with an infected person. Which measure best describes this probability? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Secondary attack rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A lot of patients presented to PHC OPD with edema, ocular problems, cardiac failure. Several deaths were reported too. There was a common history of buying oil from a local grocery store. Drug inspector will use the following test to detect adulteration. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paper chromatography test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epidemic dropsy is caused by the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with Argemone Mexicana oil, and the most sensitive test for detecting this adulteration is the paper chromatography test.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male travels frequently and has food during his travels. He presents to PHC OPD with abdominal pain, fever for 4 days. He has bradycardia too. Test for confirmation of diagnosis: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Blood culture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For typhoid fever diagnosis in the first week of illness, blood culture is the most appropriate and reliable test.
  • ➤ blood culture
  • ➤ Mnemonic – BASU
  • ➤ Mnemonic – BASU
  • ➤ Blood culture – 1 st week onwards

  • ➤ Stool culture – 3 rd week onwards

questions.text: What dose of iron and folic acid should an anemic pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024

options.label: A
options.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid twice a week

options.label: B
options.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a week

options.label: C
options.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily

options.label: D
options.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a month

questions.correct_answer: C. 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, which aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia in India by 3 percentage points every year, the "6 by 6 by 6" strategy is used. This strategy targets 6 beneficiaries, includes 6 interventions, and involves 6 institutional mechanisms.
  • • One of the interventions is iron and folic acid supplementation.
  • • Anemic pregnant women in their second trimester should be given 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days, as per the guidelines of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program.
  • • For pregnant women, the recommended dose is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days during pregnancy. This is provided in the form of red-colored tablets. The same dose is also given to lactating mothers for 180 days post-delivery.
  • • 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days
  • • If the woman does not respond to this dosage or is anemic, then other forms of iron supplementation, such as ferrous carboxy maltose and IV sucrose , may be considered.
  • • ferrous carboxy maltose and IV sucrose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Not included in STEPS approach for Non-communicable diseases is (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blood grouping

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The WHO STEPS approach for non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factor & STROKE surveillance involves three steps: behavioral measurements, physical measurements, and biochemical measurements. These steps focus on key indicators related to NCDs and stroke surveillance.
  • • non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factor & STROKE surveillance
  • • The specific indicators include:
  • • The specific indicators include:
  • • Step 1: Behavioral measurements – (for both core & expanded indicators) Tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, exercise, history of raised blood pressure, and diabetes mellitus. Step 2: Physical measurements - Core indicators include height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure; expanded indicators include hip circumference and heart rate. Step 3: Biochemical measurements - Core indicators include blood glucose and blood lipids; expanded indicators include triglycerides and serum cholesterol levels.
  • • Step 1: Behavioral measurements – (for both core & expanded indicators) Tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, exercise, history of raised blood pressure, and diabetes mellitus.
  • • Step 1: Behavioral measurements
  • • Step 2: Physical measurements - Core indicators include height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure; expanded indicators include hip circumference and heart rate.
  • • Step 2: Physical measurements
  • • Step 3: Biochemical measurements - Core indicators include blood glucose and blood lipids; expanded indicators include triglycerides and serum cholesterol levels.
  • • Step 3: Biochemical measurements
  • • Blood grouping is not a part of the STEPS approach as it does not relate to the risk factors or measurements for NCDs.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Blood sugar: Included as a core biochemical measurement (blood glucose).
  • • Option A. Blood sugar:
  • • Option B. Blood pressure: Included as a core physical measurement.
  • • Option B. Blood pressure:
  • • Option D. Blood lipids: Included as a core biochemical measurement.
  • • Option D. Blood lipids:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO STEPS approach for NCD risk factor surveillance includes behavioral, physical, and biochemical measurements, but blood grouping is not included in these indicators.

questions.text: There were 4000 live births in a community in a year. Do MMR Calculation if you come to know that 6 women died during pregnancy, labor/delivery, or within 42 days of delivery - 2 due to Obstructed labor, 1 due to Sepsis, 1 due to PPH, 1 due to Snake bite and 1 due to electrocution. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 100

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, considering only deaths directly related to pregnancy or its complications.

questions.text: What method is most effective for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence within a given area over time? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Line graph

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Line graphs are the most effective method for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence over time, making them ideal for identifying and analyzing trends in epidemiological data.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Common intermittent source epidemic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The graph shows cases occurring at irregular intervals with gaps between them, indicating that people are exposed intermittently to the source of infection. This pattern is characteristic of a common intermittent source epidemic , where exposures occur sporadically, leading to multiple peaks over time.
  • • common intermittent source epidemic
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic: Characterized by a sudden rise and fall in the number of cases within a single incubation period, showing a single peak.
  • • Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic:
  • • Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic: Shows multiple peaks due to repeated exposures, but the rise and fall are not as sudden and are marked by secondary waves.
  • • Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic:
  • • Options C. Propagated epidemic: Involves person-to-person transmission, typically showing a slow rise, a plateau, and a slow fall in the number of cases over time.
  • • Options C. Propagated epidemic:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A common intermittent source epidemic is marked by cases appearing at irregular intervals, reflecting intermittent exposures to the source of infection.

questions.text: Rukmani is attending a Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme. How frequently is it conducted? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Every month

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Programme, which Rukmani is attending, is conducted once every month by the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee.

questions.text: Bowing of legs with bleeding gums is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bowing of legs can be mistakenly attributed to vitamin D deficiency, which typically causes rickets in children.
  • • However, the presence of bleeding gums points specifically to vitamin C deficiency.
  • • Vitamin C is crucial for collagen synthesis and other structural aspects of bone formation. This deficiency, known as scurvy, involves various skeletal changes including defective osteoid matrix formation and osteolysis, beyond just the commonly noted bleeding gums. The combined symptoms of bowing of legs and bleeding gums can indeed suggest a scenario where vitamin C deficiency plays a contributory role alongside other deficiencies like vitamin D.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Vitamin A: Incorrect because Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and epithelial tissues, not typically associated with bleeding gums or significant skeletal changes like bowing of legs.
  • • Option
  • • B. Vitamin A:
  • • Option C. Vitamin E: Incorrect as Vitamin E deficiency generally leads to neurological problems and muscle weakness, not directly linked with bleeding gums or bone deformities.
  • • Option
  • • C. Vitamin E:
  • • Option D. Vitamin K: Incorrect because while Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, its deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of legs; it would rather lead to bleeding issues without the skeletal deformities noted here.
  • • Option
  • • D. Vitamin K:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin C deficiency can cause bleeding gums and is associated with significant bone structure changes, leading to conditions like scurvy that may present with skeletal deformities such as bowing of legs.

questions.text: Which of the options below does NOT result in water hardness? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Calcium carbonate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hardness of water is defined as the ‘soap destroying power of water’ Hardness of water is expressed in terms of: milliequivalents per litre (mEq/litre) of CALCIUM CARBONATE (CaCO3) 1 mEq/litre hardness = 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) per litre of water Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness > 3 mEq/litre (>150 mg/litre of Calcium carbonate) Temporary hardness of water is due to Ca++ and Mg++ Bicarbonates Permanent hardness (Non-Carbonate hardness) is due to Calcium & Magnesium salts of Sulfates, Chlorides, Nitrates Four main compounds causing Hardness: Calcium bicarbonates, Magnesium bicarbonates, Calcium sulfates, Magnesium sulfates.
  • ➤ Hardness of water is defined as the ‘soap destroying power of water’
  • ➤ Hardness of water is expressed in terms of: milliequivalents per litre (mEq/litre) of CALCIUM CARBONATE (CaCO3)
  • ➤ 1 mEq/litre hardness = 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) per litre of water
  • ➤ Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness > 3 mEq/litre (>150 mg/litre of Calcium carbonate)
  • ➤ Temporary hardness of water is due to Ca++ and Mg++ Bicarbonates
  • ➤ Permanent hardness (Non-Carbonate hardness) is due to Calcium & Magnesium salts of Sulfates, Chlorides, Nitrates
  • ➤ Four main compounds causing Hardness: Calcium bicarbonates, Magnesium bicarbonates, Calcium sulfates, Magnesium sulfates.

questions.text: A child presented to PHC OPD with skin rash and depigmented hair. He gives a history of swollen/bleeding gums. X-ray picture is shown below. He is suffering from: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Copper deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Copper deficiency can mimic vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) in its clinical and radiological presentation, a condition often referred to as pseudoscurvy.

questions.text: A female presented to the OPD within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse. Which contraception is advised? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IUCD

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the case of a female presenting within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse, the most effective emergency contraceptive (interceptive) method advised is the intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD).
  • • The IUCD is the recommended method of choice for emergency contraception with the highest efficacy and least failure rate when used within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Misoprostol: This option is incorrect because misoprostol is not an emergency contraceptive method.
  • • Option
  • • B. Misoprostol:
  • • Option C. LNG: Levonorgestrel (LNG) is a widely accepted method of emergency contraception and is recommended as a first-line option. However, its effectiveness is optimal only within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, with significantly reduced efficacy beyond this timeframe. And an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) remains the most effective alternative, providing protection for up to 5 days post-intercourse.
  • • Option
  • • C. LNG:
  • • Option D. OCP: This option is incorrect. While combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are an option, they are not the recommended method of choice when the female presents within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.
  • • Option
  • • D. OCP:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommended emergency contraceptive method currently in use are –
  • ➤ OCPs (Yuzpe and Lancee Method) – (pills with 30 mcg oestrogen) - 4 pills immediately followed by 4 pills 12 hours later. This method can be used till 72hrs of intercourse. Mini Pills (POP): Progesterone only Pill (POP) 0.75 mg – Pill has to be ‘used within 72 hours of intercourse (LNG oral tablet (0.75 mg): 1st tablet within 72 hours of intercourse and 2nd tablet after 12 hours of first dose) IUCD (most effective; highest efficacy & least failure) – can be used till 5 days RU486 (mifepristone) – within 72 hours High dose of estrogen – to be continuously used for 5 days
  • ➤ OCPs (Yuzpe and Lancee Method) – (pills with 30 mcg oestrogen) - 4 pills immediately followed by 4 pills 12 hours later. This method can be used till 72hrs of intercourse.
  • ➤ Mini Pills (POP): Progesterone only Pill (POP) 0.75 mg – Pill has to be ‘used within 72 hours of intercourse (LNG oral tablet (0.75 mg): 1st tablet within 72 hours of intercourse and 2nd tablet after 12 hours of first dose)
  • ➤ IUCD (most effective; highest efficacy & least failure) – can be used till 5 days
  • ➤ IUCD (most effective; highest efficacy & least failure) – can be used till 5 days
  • ➤ RU486 (mifepristone) – within 72 hours
  • ➤ High dose of estrogen – to be continuously used for 5 days

questions.text: Which disease the girl is related to and what's her name? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sapna, Leprosy

questions.explanation:

questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: Which compound among the options is predominantly responsible for the disinfectant quality to bleaching powder? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypochlorous acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bleaching powder (CaOCl 2 )
  • ➤ Bleaching powder (CaOCl 2 )
  • ➤ 2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.
  • ➤ 2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.
  • ➤ Mechanism of action:
  • ➤ CHLORINE + IMPURITIES à DESTRUCTION Add some additional Cl 2 [free residual Cl 2 ] Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]
  • ➤ CHLORINE + IMPURITIES à DESTRUCTION Add some additional Cl 2 [free residual Cl 2 ]
  • ➤ Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]
  • ➤ H 2 O + Cl → HCI + HOCI HOCI → H + OCI

questions.text: As per the new guidelines of MTP Act, Medical termination of pregnancy can be done after 24 weeks for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Foetus malformation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the new guidelines of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, as amended in 2021, medical termination of pregnancy is permitted in India up to 24 weeks of gestation.
  • • Beyond 24 weeks , MTP is permissible in cases where there are documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations . In such cases, the opinion of the state medical board is required to proceed with the termination.
  • • Beyond 24 weeks
  • • substantial fetal anomalies or malformations
  • • state medical board
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Rape: This option is incorrect because, while rape or sexual assault is one of the indications for MTP up to 24 weeks, it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.
  • • Option A. Rape:
  • • Option B. Contraceptive failure: This option is incorrect because contraceptive failure is a social indication for MTP up to 24 weeks, but it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.
  • • Option B. Contraceptive failure:
  • • Option D. Insanity: This option is incorrect as it is not mentioned as an indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.
  • • Option D. Insanity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As per the new guidelines of the MTP Act in India, medical termination of pregnancy can be performed beyond 24 weeks of gestation only in cases of documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations, and the opinion of the state medical board is required.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to OPD with fever and neurological complications. He was having respiratory difficulty during the examination. Identify the disease transmitted through the life cycle shown in the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nipah virus disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nipah virus is transmitted through contact with Pteropus bats, contaminated food, or animals that have been exposed to the virus. It causes severe respiratory and neurological symptoms with a high fatality rate and no available vaccine.

questions.text: Within the framework of Sustainable Development Goal 3, the objective of target 3.1 is to achieve a reduction in the Maternal Mortality Ratio to what specific level (per 1 lakh live births) by the year 2030? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) <70

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SDGs – Targets & Indicators
  • ➤ SDGs – Targets & Indicators
  • ➤ 3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70
  • ➤ 3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25
  • ➤ 3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.
  • ➤ 3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.
  • ➤ 3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.
  • ➤ 3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.
  • ➤ 3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.
  • ➤ 3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.
  • ➤ 3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text: Under the Urban health care system of India, the following health centre is not included: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) District hospital

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • District hospitals, however, are not a part of the urban healthcare system's primary or secondary level facilities, hence they are not included.
  • • Urban Health care system of India
  • • Urban Health care system of India
  • • There is a provision for creating urban health and wellness centres , which cater to a population of 15,000 to 20,000. These centres are akin to primary health centres (PHCs) in rural areas. Additionally, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), previously known as Urban Health Centres , serve a population of 50,000 . Urban polyclinics are created for a population of 2.5 to 3 lakh . At the secondary level, Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC) are established for a population of 2.5 lakh in non-metro cities and 5 lakh in metro cities .
  • • There is a provision for creating urban health and wellness centres , which cater to a population of 15,000 to 20,000.
  • • urban health and wellness centres
  • • population of 15,000 to 20,000.
  • • These centres are akin to primary health centres (PHCs) in rural areas. Additionally, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), previously known as Urban Health Centres , serve a population of 50,000 .
  • • Urban Health Centres
  • • 50,000
  • • Urban polyclinics are created for a population of 2.5 to 3 lakh .
  • • Urban polyclinics
  • • population of 2.5 to 3 lakh
  • • At the secondary level, Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC) are established for a population of 2.5 lakh in non-metro cities and 5 lakh in metro cities .
  • • Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC)
  • • population of 2.5 lakh in non-metro cities and 5 lakh in metro cities

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ District hospitals are not included in the urban healthcare system of India; instead, urban health facilities include Urban Health and Wellness Centres, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), Urban Polyclinics, and Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC).

questions.text: The term "paradoxical carrier" is defined as: (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period

options.label: B
options.text: A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier

options.label: C
options.text: A person who acquired pathogen from patient

options.label: D
options.text: A patient who became a carrier

questions.correct_answer: B. A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A paradoxical carrier is a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, but who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease. Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence. Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.
  • ➤ A paradoxical carrier is a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, but who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease.
  • ➤ paradoxical carrier
  • ➤ Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease.
  • ➤ Incubatory carriers
  • ➤ Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence.
  • ➤ Convalescent carriers
  • ➤ Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.
  • ➤ Healthy carriers

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is bitten by a stray dog. She had received post-exposure prophylaxis for a monkey bite two months ago. What is the appropriate management for her current rabies exposure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Wound care + IM vaccine 0,3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For individuals with a recent history of rabies vaccination (within the past three months), re-exposure prophylaxis includes wound care and two doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

questions.text: What is the prevalence of a disease with an incidence of a disease of 4 cases per 1000 individuals in the population and an average duration of 2 years? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 8/1000

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prevalence can be calculated using the formula:
  • ➤ Prevalence = Incidence x Duration.
  • ➤ Prevalence = Incidence x Duration.

questions.text: A public health official notes that there were 60 infant deaths and 5,000 live births in the past year. What denominator should she use to calculate the infant mortality rate? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 1000

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The standard denominator for calculating and expressing the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is 1000 live births.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man from a rural area of Bihar presents to the outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital in Patna. He has been experiencing fever for the past week, associated with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, and palpable lymphadenopathy. Despite being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and antimalarial agents by a local practitioner, there's been no significant relief. Blood investigations for typhoid (Widal test) are negative; however, the rk39 dipstick test is positive. Based on the clinical picture and the diagnostic findings, what would be the most appropriate drug of choice for the treatment of his condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Liposomal Amphotericin B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) should be treated with liposomal amphotericin B, especially when diagnosed with a positive rk39 dipstick test.
  • ➤ Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) should be treated with liposomal amphotericin B, especially when diagnosed with a positive rk39 dipstick test.
